body: The title and description are a little misleading. We aren't really "fixing missed callbacks"; it's more like we notify for every change instead of batching them into one refresh() call?
Will propose the `OnDemandProperty` in another separate PR

Commit message:

Implement MaxCapacityUsageInstanceConstraint soft constraint
- The constraint evaluates the score by checking the max used capacity key out of all the capacity
keys.
- The higher the maximum usage value for the capacity key, the lower the score will be, implying
that it is that much less desirable to assign anything on the given node.
- It is a greedy approach since it evaluates only on the most used capacity key.

Maybe a cleaner/better solution is to refactor the code and support `/namespaces` even no default namespace is set.

> If the constraint factory/wagedRebalancer fails to produce the mapping, should we put the cluster in maintenance mode or treat it as a NOP? I'd like to guide us to think about in what scenarios putting the cluster under maintenance would be appropriate.

The current design returns the previous mapping if a calculation fails (this is not done yet). Entering maintenance mode means we need to auto exist as well. This makes maintenance mode management more complicated. So I would prefer keeping it simple for now.

Final comment for the commit:
title: 
Fix missed callbacks in CurrentStates based RoutingTableProvider.
description: 
1. Update BasicClusterDataCache to do refresh with selective update. Only when a change happens, we do the cache refresh only for that change type.
2. Improve RoutingTableProvider.queueEvent() and RoutingTableProvider.handleEvent(). Return instanceConfigs snapshot to callback immediately, instead of waiting for currentStates completion.

The PR is ready to merge into wagedRebalancer, approved by @jiajunwang @narendly 

Commit message:

Implement MaxCapacityUsageInstanceConstraint soft constraint

The constraint evaluates the score by checking the max used capacity key out of all the capacity
keys.
The higher the maximum usage value for the capacity key, the lower the score will be, implying
that it is that much less desirable to assign anything on the given node.
It is a greedy approach since it evaluates only the most used capacity key.
@lei-xia Unit test added: TestCustomRebalancer.
This PR is ready to be merged, approved by @lei-xia

Commit message:

[helix-rest] Delete unused default namespace (api "/namespaces/default") #449 

We have a namespace api: /admin/v2/namespaces/{namespace}/. However, the /namespaces/default path is not in use. We need to delete it. On the code level,
if there is not a default namespace, we won't create a DEFAULT_SERVLET.
On the app level, we can configure app not to add name "default" namespace.
With this change, endpoint /admin/v2/namespaces/ will be disable if no namespace
sets IS_DEFAULT to true.

commit message:

Add soft constraint: partition movement constraint
 * Evaluate the proposed assignment according to the potential partition movements cost.
 * The cost is evaluated based on the difference between the old assignment and the new assignment.

The simple inverse function has an issue where max value is not constrained.
I found the sigmoid function (widely used in logistic regression) more aligned with our requirement:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_function

![640px-Logistic-curve svg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2618776/65189425-c1b4af80-da25-11e9-830e-9686ee5f81fc.png)

Final commit comment:

Add Intellij code style XML file so we can import it into Intellij to configure java code style for Helix.

A better alternative function is $$f(x) = tanh(1/x)$$

The function plot looks like 
![save](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2618776/65278274-a064c980-dae0-11e9-8e57-8c55bf09679a.png)

It satisfies 
- continues distribution between (0, 1]
- The value decreases when x >= 0
- When x == 0, the value is infinitely close to 1 

The X in soft constraint mostly defines the usage of some aspect (X >= 0). The lower usage is generally encouraged and higher usage is discouraged.
@pkuwm Could you create a how-to guide or instructions wiki so people know what to do/expect?
@pkuwm That still doesn't answer my question. Was this originally a bug in the routing cache? Or are you having to fix this as a result of some recent change?

Which calculation is faster? And I would prefer sigmoid. I think it differentiates better when assigned partition count is a small number. And that is our major concerns.
We won't handle very full clusters usually.

> @pkuwm Could you create a how-to guide or instructions wiki so people know what to do/expect?

Right. This in in my plan. Will do it by end of this week.

$$tanh(x) = \frac{e^{2x} - 1}{e^{2x} + 1}$$
$$sigmoid(x) = \frac{1}{1 + e ^ {x}}$$
The calculation speed is same. I would prefer the tanh because I can show you to make sigmoid value = 0 when x == 0 is much harder, whereas the tanh by nature closes to 1 when x nears 0.

The second part is we can tune the paramter inside, e.g, 
$$f(x) = tanh( 1 / \alpha x)$$
Different alpha parameter would lead to differen kind of shapes

$$f(x) = tanh( 1 / 10x)$$
![save (1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2618776/65280418-2256f180-dae5-11e9-8799-d588167e6478.png)
$$f(x) = tanh( 1 / 0.1x)$$
![save (2)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2618776/65280419-22ef8800-dae5-11e9-9170-39908186a6e7.png)

> @pkuwm That still doesn't answer my question. Was this originally a bug in the routing cache? Or are you having to fix this as a result of some recent change?

From my understanding, it originally was done on purpose as current state refresh uses selective update. I wouldn't say it was a bug in the routing cache as it did not affect correctness. But it actually did not reset _propertyDataChangeMap for current states cache. Each time current states cache would be refreshed. So performance may be impacted. Resetting _propertyDataChangeMap for current state would help the performance.

To the reviewers, this is only for testing and evaluation. It should not impact business logic.
And the tool will be continuously modified as we have different simulation requirement.

@jiajunwang @narendly, this is the PR that optimizes the soft constraint function as we've reached an agreement with the meeting today.

The first several commits, let's focus on reviewing and refining the big picture of how the scoring method should work: interface, detailed tuning parameter setup, etc.

Once the big picture is agreed, I can focus on the detail implementations: unit test refining, etc.

The PR won't address the dynamical configurations of the soft constraints' weights as it's a different topic.

This PR is ready to be merged, approved by @narendly.

Final Commit Message:

Title:
Change the way Helix triggers rebalance

Body:
A method is added which generates OnDemandRebalance event.
This event cause the controller to run rebalance pipeline for both of the pipelines.
Touch logics have been removed and replaced by this new method.

Updated the mvn test result.

Closing this PR. Issue will be updated accordingly with new findings.

Here is the outcome of the investigation on FixedTargetedTasks:
1- These tasks will be assigned to the instances based on the on the outcome of the class:FixedTargetTaskAssignmentCalculator -> function:computeAssignmentAndChargeResource.

2- In the function:updatePreviousAssignedTasksStatus of the class:AbstractTaskDispatcher, whenever currentState is INIT (currentState==INIT or (currentState==null and Context==INIT) or (currentState==null and Context==null)), this partition will be added to assignedPartitions and will be excluded from being assignment in the method mentioned in Step1. In conclusion, whenever this task is targeted task, it makes sense to not take any decision about this task and let the FixedTargetTaskAssignmentCalculator to decide on the new assignment of the targeted task.

3- However, for the cases where current state is actually INIT, we might not have any assignment, because in function:computeAssignmentAndChargeResource, line 260: in condition "prevInstance.equals(instance)", we break and there won't be any assignment. As a result, this break should be removed which allows this function to take new decision for the tasks.

4- Finally, with these changes, One of the tests will fails. This test is called TestTaskNumAttempts.
The reason is potentially related to pending messages and race condition that can happen when there is pending message for the tasks.

5- More investigation is needed.

The problem has been seen when the Queue config does not follow the semantics of Queue and some jobs have multiple children and multiple parents. This avoids the job to be removed from the DAG and overwhelms the logs.
The PR is ready to merge into WagedRebalancer branch, approved by @jiajunwang

> Thanks for fixing the typo.
> 
> Note that this will probably create a new metric. Historical data emitted by the old metric before deployment of this new change will still have to be accessed using the old name.

You are right. I was hesitated to change this typo. For future deployment, we may need to change the name in metric collector.

> Suggestion on the description of the PR. You say "a more strict check", but you don't actually describe it. So the reviewer has no clue what the "more strict check" should be. I think if you could actually describe it, something like, "previously, if a resource's weight is not set, we consider it 0. But we will change that behavior so that if a resource's weight is not set, we will throw an exception and halt the rebalancing."
> Then the reviewer knows what to watch out for and whether the code change actually reflects that change.

Sure. Updated the description.
